title: Introduction
text: Clustergrammer is a visualization library built using D3.js that enables intuitive interaction with high-dimensional data.
Clustergrammer was built with biological data in mind and this example shows kinase gene expression levels obtained from the CCLE.
Scroll down to take an interactive tour.

title: Enrichment Analysis
text: Users can run enrichment analysis on their genes (where genes are rows) using Enrichr.
Clicking the Enrichr logo brings up an Enrichr menu with a list of available libraries.
Scroll down to run an example enrichment or click a library.

title: Enrichment Analysis
text: Clicking on the ChEA 2015 library sends your gene list to Enrichr and resturns the top 10 enriched transcription factors as row categories.
You can send subsets of gene lists to Enrichr using the dendrogram to select subsets of genes.

title: Enrichment Analysis
text: You can clear your results by opening the Enrichr menu and clicking 'Clear Results'

title: Zooming and Panning
text: Zoom and pan by scrolling and dragging the matrix.

title: Reordering using buttons
text: Rows and columns can be reordered using the reorder buttons.
Here rows are being ordered based on their variance.

title: More reordering options
text: You can also reorder the matrix based on the data in a single row/column or category by double-clicking its label.
Here rows are being ordered based on the values in the row EGFR.
Try double-clicking a row/column or category label to reorder.

title: Filter rows
text: Filtering your data to reduce dimensionality can be useful for investegating complex datasets.
Clustergrammer allows you to filter your rows based on their sum or variance - here we are filtering for the top 10 rows based on variance.

title: Conclusion
text: The Clustergrammer web app can be found here and the Jupyter/IPython widget can be found here
Clustergrammer is an open source project available on GitHub.
